channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Prisoner Swaps Completed as Russia Fires Barrage at Kyiv
item.description: The third day of prisoner exchanges between Russia and Ukraine went ahead as planned on Sunday, wrapping up a program agreed to earlier this month, hours after a second night of deadly missile and drone strikes across much of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ros Krasny, Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: A high-rise residential building heavily damaged by a Russian drone strike in Kyiv on May 25. Photographer: Vitalii Nosach/Global Images Ukraine/Getty Images

item.title: Polish Presidential Hopefuls Rally Supporters Before Vote
item.description: Supporters of Poland’s presidential contenders took to the streets of Warsaw on Sunday for parallel marches that highlight deep divisions in the European Union nation a week before a tightly-contested runoff election.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Ojewska, Piotr Bujnicki

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowski, his wife Malgorzata and Poland’s Prime Minister, Donald Tusk walk with Supporters during the Great Patriotic March a week before the second round of the presidential elections on May 25.

item.title: Israel's Latest Strikes in Gaza Kill 38 People Including Children
item.description: DEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) — Israeli strikes over the past 24 hours killed at least 38 people in Gaza, including a mother and her two children sheltering in a tent, local health officials said Sunday, with no data available for a second straight day from now-inaccessible hospitals in the north.

media:content.media:description: People watch as smoke billows following an Israeli strike in Jabalia, in the northern Gaza Strip on May 25, 2025.

item.title: US Risks Losing ‘Reliable Investment’ Status, Allianz GI Manager Says
item.description: Inside one of Europe’s biggest asset managers, there’s growing concern that Republican efforts to gut legislation supporting key industries such as clean energy may result in the US losing its status as a destination for investor capital.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Marsh

item.title: Macron Kicks Off Asia Tour in Vietnam With Focus on Energy
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron is expected to focus on energy, transport and infrastructure during his state visit to Vietnam, the first stop of his Southeast Asian tour as he seeks to shore up alliances in the region.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Stevens, Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron

item.title: German Finance Minister Urges Calm in US Tariff Fight, Bild Says
item.description: German Finance Minister Lars Klingbeil urged restraint in the escalating trade dispute between the European Union and the US in an interview with Bild am Sonntag.
item.dc:creator: Eva Brendel

media:content.media:description: Lars Klingbeil during a session at the Bundestag in Berlin, on May 15.

item.title: North Korea Detains Officials After Failed Warship Launch: KCNA
item.description: North Korea has detained key officials following a failed launch that damaged a destroyer, state media reported.
item.dc:creator: Yoolim Lee

media:content.media:description: CHONGJIN, NORTH KOREA -- MAY 23, 2025: 02 Maxar satellite imagery taken at 2:01 PM local time shows the aftermath of an accident at the Hambuk Shipyard during the launch of a new destroyer. The vessel is seen listing heavily and partially covered with blue tarps, indicating a potential failure during launch and efforts to conceal the extent of damage. Please use: Satellite image (c) 2025 Maxar Technologies.

item.title: Australia’s Opposition Parties on Track to Return to Coalition
item.description: Australia’s two center-right opposition parties appear to be on track to return to the Coalition, a longstanding alliance between the pair that suffered a surprise split last week in the wake of a disastrous election showing.
item.dc:creator: Michael Heath

media:content.media:description: CANBERRA, AUSTRALIA - SEPTEMBER 01: National Party leader David Littleproud attends a jobs and skills summit at Parliament House on September 1, 2022 in Canberra, Australia. The Australian government is bringing together political, business, union and community group leaders at Parliament House to address issues facing the Australian economy and workforce as inflation and interest rates continue to rise. (Photo by Martin Ollman/Getty Images)

item.title: Russia Steps Up Airstrikes on Ukraine’s Capital After POW Swap
item.description: Russia intensified its attacks on Ukraine’s capital, firing drones and missiles overnight after a seven-hour barrage of Kyiv on Saturday that was one of the most sustained in the four-year war.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska, Kateryna Chursina

media:content.media:description: Firefighter clear debris from a balcony at a residential building damaged after a Russian attack in Kyiv on May 24. Photographer: Alex Babenko/AP Photo

item.title: Billionaires Boost Cuomo’s Fundraising Lead in NYC Mayor’s Race
item.description: Former Governor Andrew Cuomo expanded his commanding fundraising lead in the New York City mayoral race with help from a few billionaire donors, according to newly published numbers filed with the city’s Campaign Finance Board.
item.dc:creator: Laura Nahmias, Amanda L Gordon

media:content.media:description: Andrew Cuomo, center, marches in the Celebrate Israel Parade up Fifth Avenue in New York on May 18, 2025.

item.title: Polish Ruling-Party Candidate Pushes Back Against Far Right
item.description: Warsaw Mayor Rafal Trzaskowski, who narrowly won the first round of Poland’s presidential election, is pushing back against the far right ahead of his runoff with opposition candidate Karol Nawrocki on June 1.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Bujnicki

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowski arrives at a polling station in Warsaw, Poland, on May 18

item.title: Nine of a Doctor's 10 Children Are Killed in Israel's Latest Strikes in Gaza
item.description: CAIRO (AP) — The bodies of 79 people killed by Israeli strikes have been brought to hospitals in the past 24 hours, Gaza 's Health Ministry said Saturday, a toll that doesn't include hospitals in the battered north that it said are now inaccessible.

media:content.media:description: Civil defense teams carry bodies of victims following an Israeli airstrike on residential areas in central Khan Yunis, southern Gaza, on May 23, 2025.

item.title: Salvador-Style Emergency Powers On Track for Noboa’s Ecuador
item.description: Fresh off his unexpectedly strong election win, Ecuador’s President Daniel Noboa, sworn in Saturday, is seeking to cement his authority with a crime bill that would give his government emergency powers of the kind used in El Salvador.
item.dc:creator: Stephan Kueffner

media:content.media:description: Daniel Noboa greets supporters from the balcony of the Carondelet Palace in Quito on May 24. Photographer: David Diaz Arcos/Bloomberg

item.title: Planned Parenthood Affiliate to Close Clinics in Iowa, Minnesota
item.description: Four of the six Planned Parenthood clinics in Iowa and four in Minnesota will shut down in a year, the Midwestern affiliate operating them said Friday, blaming a freeze in federal funds, budget cuts proposed in Congress and state restrictions on abortion.

media:content.media:description: The Planned Parenthood Reproductive Health Services Center in St. Louis, Missouri, May 30, 2019.

item.title: US Plans Chevron License for Minimum Upkeep in Venezuela
item.description: The Trump administration is preparing to issue a narrowly tailored license to Chevron Corp., allowing the oil producer to conduct minimal maintenance of essential operations in Venezuela, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin, Andreina Itriago

media:content.media:description: A Petroleos de Venezuela SA (PDVSA) oil pumpjack on Lake Maracaibo in Cabimas, Zulia state, Venezuela, on Wednesday, Nov. 15, 2023. A decision by the US on Oct. 18 to ease sanctions in exchange for greater political freedom in Venezuela, has opened the doors for dealmaking and increased production that will enable the Latin American country's crude to reach global markets. Photographer: Gaby Oraa/Bloomberg

item.title: Harvard Reprieve for Foreign Students Won’t Stop Looming Threats
item.description: Harvard University can continue to enroll international students – for now.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos, Janet Lorin

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians enter the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Wednesday, April 16, 2025. President Donald Trump escalated his administration's fight with Harvard University by threatening its tax-exempt status after the school defied the government's demands to change its policies in exchange for billions of dollars of federal funding.

item.title: Buy American: How Europe Must Stock Up On Weapons for Ukraine
item.description: European leaders are racing to figure out how to keep Ukraine supplied with weapons as US President Donald Trump appears to be walking away from the war. One option: buy American.
item.dc:creator: Courtney McBride, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Soldiers load missiles for a Patriot air defense system. With two Patriot systems in Poland, Rzeszow, on Jan. 23, 2025.

item.title: Trump’s New Tariff Threats Show Trade Uncertainty Here to Stay
item.description: Investors were growing optimistic that Donald Trump’s trade wars had started to calm down. His latest tariff broadsides quickly disabused them of that notion.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: A worker helps load containers onto the Columbia Elizabeth barge at the Port of Philadelphia in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, US, on Wednesday, March 5, 2025. The dollar dropped the most since US President Donald Trump took office this year as concerns about the negative impact of US tariffs on the economy weigh on the greenback, with losses particularly stark against the euro.

item.title: Bangladesh’s Interim Government Says It Will Stay the Course
item.description: Bangladesh’s interim government has no intention of stepping down before completing its responsibilities, a top cabinet member said, rejecting speculation over a possible resignation of its leader Muhammad Yunus.
item.dc:creator: Arun Devnath

media:content.media:description: Muhammad Yunus Photographer: Munir Uz Zaman/Getty Images

item.title: Turkey’s Top Diplomat Heads for Russia to Discuss Ukraine, Syria
item.description: Turkey’s foreign minister is set to travel to Russia on Monday to discuss the situation in Ukraine, following direct talks earlier this month in Istanbul between the two sides in conflict.
item.dc:creator: Baris Balci

media:content.media:description: Hakan Fidan Photographer: Ahmed Hasan/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: UK Officials Probe Russian Involvement in Starmer Fires, FT Says
item.description: UK security officials are probing if Russia could be involved in three arson attacks related to Prime Minister Keir Starmer, according to the Financial Times.
item.dc:creator: Sam Unsted

media:content.media:description: A view of the entrance of a property linked to Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer in Islington, north London, after a suspected arson attack.

item.title: EU Weighs Cutting 20 Banks From SWIFT in New Russia Sanctions
item.description: The European Union is considering cutting more than 20 banks from SWIFT, the international payments system, as well as lowering a price cap on Russian oil and banning the Nord Stream gas pipelines as part of a new sanctions package that aims to increase pressure on Moscow to end its war against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Ewa Krukowska

item.title: India, Pakistan Battle for Global Sympathy After Border Truce
item.description: Two weeks after pulling back from the brink of all-out war, India and Pakistan are now racing to win over global opinion.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen, Kamran Haider, Dan Strumpf, Swati Gupta

media:content.media:description: TOPSHOT - An Indian army soldier stands guard near the Line of Control (LoC) in India's Kashmir region on May 19, 2025. (Photo by TAUSEEF MUSTAFA / AFP) (Photo by TAUSEEF MUSTAFA/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Forces Switzerland to Question Its Love for Farmers
item.description: Switzerland’s bid for a US trade deal risks sparking a showdown with one political force at least as feisty as President Donald Trump: its own farmers.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Mountain pasture in Switzerland. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Shocks With US Steel-Nippon Approval But Details Elusive
item.description: President Donald Trump on Friday announced a partnership between United States Steel Corp. and Japan’s Nippon Steel Corp., shocking markets with an agreement he said would keep the once-iconic American firm in the US but otherwise providing no specifics.
item.dc:creator: Joe Deaux, Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Emissions rise from chimneys at the Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal Corp. plant in Kashima, Japan. Photographer: Tomohiro Ohsumi/Bloomberg

item.title: Malaysia’s Anwar Defends Lengthening Tenure of Anti-Graft Chief
item.description: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim defended an extension of the anti-corruption agency head’s tenure, saying Azam Baki has been brave in going after powerful figures allegedly embroiled in corruption and abuse of power.
item.dc:creator: Anuradha Raghu

media:content.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's prime minister, at the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday, Jan. 22, 2025. The annual Davos gathering of political leaders, top executives and celebrities runs from January 20 to 24.

item.title: Japan Signals Intent to Reach US Tariff Deal by G-7 in June
item.description: Japan’s chief trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa indicated his aim to resolve tariff talks in time for a June meeting between US President Donald Trump and Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba following Trump’s surprise pivot to allow a partnership between two of the countries’ steelmakers.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa, Japan’s chief tariff negotiator, speaks to reporters at Tokyo’s Haneda airport on May 23, 2025, before departing for the United States for the third round of tariff talks with U.S. officials. (Photo by Kyodo News via Getty Images)

item.title: China Jets Used in India-Pakistan Clash Spur Defense Stock Surge
item.description: As the recent military clash between India and Pakistan stunned the world with its intensity, investors were fixated on another aspect of the conflict: the display of cutting-edge military technology.
item.dc:creator: Sangmi Cha, Ashutosh Joshi

media:content.media:description: Pakistan Air Force J-10C fighter jets, developed by China’s Avic Chengdu Aircraft Co.

item.title: US Moves to Ease Sanctions on Syria After Trump Met New Leader
item.description: The US has taken a major step toward easing severe sanctions on Syria imposed during the Assad dictatorship, which was overthrown by rebels last December after a nearly 14-year civil war.
item.dc:creator: John Harney

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, left, with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, center, and Ahmed al-Sharaa, front right, attend a meeting in Riyadh on May 14.

item.title: Trump Signs Orders to Revive US Leadership in Nuclear Power
item.description: President Donald Trump on Friday signed orders meant to accelerate the construction of nuclear power plants, including small, untested designs that offer the promise of rapid deployment but haven’t yet been built in the US.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: A nuclear power station in Shippingport, Pennsylvania.
